revision.text:
{{Redirect|Christmas season}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name=Christmas and holiday season |caption=[[Christmas tree]] in Japan. Christmas is celebrated by an increasing number of non-Christians [[Christmas around the world|around the world]]. |image=Christmas tree in marunouchi.jpg |nickname= {{Plainlist| * Christmas season * Christmastime * Holiday season * The holidays * Festive season * Winter holidays ([[northern hemisphere]]) * Summer holidays ([[southern hemisphere]]) * [[Yule]]tide * New Year's holidays * Other }} |observedby=<!--Too many to name, best to leave this blank--> |begins=Late November |ends=Early January (usually after either [[New Year's Day]] or [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]]) |observances=Gift giving, family meetings, religious services, parties, other holiday-specific traditions |type=Varied |significance=[[Christian]] and secular festive season |relatedto= [[Advent]], [[Christmas Day]] ([[Christmas Eve|Eve]]), [[Boxing Day]], [[New Year's Day]] ([[New Year's Eve|Eve]]), [[Twelfth Night (holiday)|Twelfth Night]], [[Thanksgiving]] (US), [[Hanukkah]], [[Yule]], [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]], [[Kwanzaa]] (US), [[Winter solstice]], [[List of winter festivals|others]]}}
The '''Christmas season''',<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.canada.com/ottawacitizen/news/story.html?id=86b66e03-9a20-4b4b-8290-aadafccdeca4&k=11553|title=Ottawa shoppers to drop $3.2 B this Christmas season|first=Kristin|last=Goff|work=The Ottawa Citizen|quote=Ottawa shoppers are in the mood to spend this holiday season and could drop as much as $3.2 billion in retailers' tills, a new survey has found.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071126084833/http://www.canada.com/ottawacitizen/news/story.html?id=86b66e03-9a20-4b4b-8290-aadafccdeca4&k=11553|archivedate=November 26, 2007|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|work=[[The Times]]|first=James|last=Harding|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,8210-2489216,00.html|title=Real wonder of Woolies is that it still has a place on the high street |date=December 6, 2006|quote=John Lewis, too, has reported a fantastic start to the Christmas season, with sales up nearly 6 per cent on a year ago. | location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171228011413/https://www.infoplease.com/calendar-holidays/major-holidays/origins-christmas-holiday |archivedate=December 28, 2017}}</ref> also called the '''festive season''',<ref>[http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/festive-season Definition of festive season] – ''Collins Dictionary''. Retrieved August 14, 2013.</ref> or the '''holiday season''' (mainly in the U.S. and Canada; often simply called '''the holidays'''),<ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/money/industries/retail/2006-11-25-walmart_x.htm Wal-Mart sounds ominous note for holiday season] – ''USA Today''. November 25, 2006. Retrieved October 27, 2010.</ref><ref>[http://in.reuters.com/article/2009/12/02/us-cybermonday-idINTRE5B14AP20091202 Web retail a bright spot in tepid U.S. holiday season] – ''Reuters India''. December 2, 2009. Retrieved October 27, 2010.</ref> is an annually recurring period recognized in many [[Western world|Western]] and Western-influenced countries that is generally considered to run from late November to early January.<ref>{{cite web|last=Johnson|first=David|title=Origins of the Christmas Holiday |url= http://www.infoplease.com/spot/christmas1.html |publisher=infoplease|accessdate=December 24, 2013}}</ref><ref name=weight>{{Cite journal|title=A prospective study of holiday weight gain|vauthors=Yanovski JA, Yanovski SZ, Sovik KN, Nguyen TT, O'Neil PM, Sebring NG |pmid=10727591|journal=New England Journal of Medicine|date=March 23, 2000|volume=342|issue=12|pages=861–867|doi=10.1056/NEJM200003233421206|pmc=4336296}}</ref><ref name=coopers>{{cite conference|title=Christmas in Cooperstown and Templeton: The Coopers and the Invention of an American Holiday Tradition|author=Allan M. Axelrad|booktitle=14th Cooper Seminar, James Fenimore Cooper: His Country and His Art at the State University of New York College at Oneonta, July 2003|date=July 2005|editor=Hugh C. MacDougall |pages=7–18|url=http://external.oneonta.edu/cooper/articles/suny/2003suny-axelrad.html}}</ref> It is defined as incorporating at least [[Christmas]], and usually [[New Year's Day|New Year]], and sometimes various other [[holiday]]s and festivals. It also is associated with a period of shopping which comprises a [[economics of Christmas|peak season for the retail sector]] (the "Christmas (or holiday) shopping season"), and a period of sales at the end of the season (the "January sales"). [[Christmas window]] displays and [[Christmas tree lighting]] ceremonies when trees decorated with ornaments and light bulbs are illuminated, are traditions in many areas.
In the [[Christian denominations|denominations]] of [[Western Christianity]], the term "Christmas season" is considered synonymous with [[Christmastide]],<ref name=Truscott>{{cite book|quote=As with the Easter cycle, churches today celebrate the Christmas cycle in different ways. Practically all Protestants observe Christmas itself, with services on 25 December or the evening before. Anglicans, Lutherans and other churches that use the ecumenical ''Revised Common Lectionary'' will likely observe the four Sundays of Advent, maintaining the ancient emphasis on the eschatological (First Sunday), ascetic (Second and Third Sundays), and scriptural/historical (Fourth Sunday). Besides Christmas Eve/Day, they will observe a 12-day ''season'' of Christmas from 25 December to 5 January.|last=Truscott|first=Jeffrey A. |title=Worship|publisher=Armour Publishing|isbn=9789814305419|page=103}}</ref><ref>[http://www.holytrinitygerman.org/xmastide.html Christmastide] – Holytrinitygerman.org. Retrieved August 14, 2013.</ref> a term associated with [[Yuletide]], which runs from December 25 ([[Christmas Day]]) to January 5 ([[Epiphany Eve]]), popularly known as the [[Twelve Days of Christmas|12 Days of Christmas]].<ref name="Christianson2000">{{cite book|last=Christianson|first=Stephen G.|title=The American Book of Days|date=January 1, 2000|publisher=H.W. Wilson|language=English |isbn=9780824209544|quote=The last evening of the traditional Twelve Days of Christmas is known as the Twelfth Night, or Epiphany Eve.}}</ref><ref name=Truscott/> However, as the economic impact involving the anticipatory lead-up to Christmas Day grew in America and Europe into the 19th and 20th centuries, the term "Christmas season" began to become synonymous instead with the traditional Christian [[Advent]] season,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.americancatholic.org/Newsletters/CU/ac1201.asp|title=Holy Day Vs. Holiday|author=Dan Andriacco|year=2001|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140404105120/http://www.americancatholic.org/Newsletters/CU/ac1201.asp|archivedate=April 4, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> the period observed in [[Western Christianity]] from the fourth Sunday before Christmas Day until Christmas Day itself. The term "[[Advent calendar]]" survives in secular Western parlance as a term referring to a countdown to Christmas Day from the beginning of December.
Beginning in the mid-20th century, as the Christian-associated Christmas holiday became increasingly secularized and central to American economics and culture while religio-[[multiculturalism|multicultural]] sensitivity rose, generic references to the season that omitted the word "Christmas" became more common in the corporate and public sphere of the United States,<ref name="IT">{{Cite web|title=Dealing with the 'Christmas' vs. 'Holiday Season' Issue|url=http://www.itbusinessedge.com/cm/blogs/tennant/dealing-with-the-christmas-vs-holiday-season-issue/?cs=49163|author=Don Tennant|date=November 23, 2011}}</ref> which has [[Christmas controversy#Present-day controversy|caused a semantics controversy]]<ref name="RRpoll">[http://www.rasmussenreports.com/public_content/lifestyle/general_lifestyle/november_2012/68_prefer_merry_christmas_over_happy_holidays 68% Prefer 'Merry Christmas' Over 'Happy Holidays'] – ''Rasmussem Reports''. November 27, 2012. Retrieved August 14, 2013.</ref> that continues to the present. By the late 20th century, the Jewish holiday of [[Hanukkah]] and the new African American cultural holiday of [[Kwanzaa]] began to be considered in the U.S. as being part of the "holiday season", a term that as of 2013 has become equally or more prevalent than "Christmas season" in U.S. sources to refer to the end-of-the-year festive period.<ref name="IT" /><ref>[https://books.google.com/ngrams/graph?content=Christmas+season%2Choliday+season&year_start=1950&year_end=2000&corpus=15&smoothing=3&share= "Christmas season" vs. "Holiday season"] – Google Ngram Viewer. Retrieved August 14, 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/12/16/poll-us-split-on-happy-ho_1_n_797795.html Poll: U.S. Split On 'Happy Holidays' Vs. 'Merry Christmas'] – ''Huffington Post''. December 16, 2010. Retrieved August 14, 2013.</ref> "Holiday season" has also spread in varying degrees to Canada;<ref name="Canadapoll">[http://o.canada.com/2012/12/20/holiday-vs-christmas/ Humbug to Holiday: 7 in 10 Canadians Prefer '[ Merry Christmas]'] – ''Canada.com''. December 20, 2012. Retrieved August 14, 2013.– Canadian Olympic Team Official Website. Retrieved August 14, 2013.</ref> however, in the United Kingdom and Ireland, the phrase "holiday season" is not widely synonymous with the Christmas–New Year period, and is often instead associated with [[summer vacation|summer holidays]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20130806155147/http://thedx.co.uk/customerservice/holidayseasonschedule/ Holiday Season Schedules (archived)] – DX Group UK. Retrieved August 14, 2013.</ref>
== History ==
=== Roman Saturnalia ===
[[Saturnalia]] was an [[Roman festival|ancient Roman festival]] in honor of the [[List of Roman deities|deity]] [[Saturn (mythology)|Saturn]], held on December 17 of the [[Julian calendar]] and later expanded with festivities through December 23. The holiday was celebrated with a sacrifice at the [[Temple of Saturn]], in the [[Roman Forum]], and a public banquet, followed by private gift-giving, continual partying, and a [[carnival]] atmosphere that overturned [[Ancient Roman culture|Roman social norms]]: [[Dice#History|gambling]] was permitted, and masters provided table service for their [[Slavery in ancient Rome|slaves]].<ref>John F. Miller, "Roman Festivals," in ''The Oxford Encyclopedia of Ancient Greece and Rome'' (Oxford University Press, 2010), p. 172.</ref> The poet [[Catullus]] called it "the best of days."<ref>Catullus 14.15 ''(optimo dierum)'', as cited by Hans-Friedrich Mueller, "Saturn," in ''The Oxford Encyclopedia of Ancient Greece and Rome'', p. 221.</ref>
=== Christian adoption === {{further information|carnival in the Netherlands}} {{Unreferenced section|date=August 2013}}
The earliest source stating December 25 as the date of birth of [[Jesus]] was [[Hippolytus of Rome]] (170–236), written very early in the 3rd century, based on the assumption that the conception of Jesus took place at the [[Spring equinox]] which he placed on March 25, and then added nine months.<ref>{{cite book |title=Mercer Dictionary of the Bible |last=Mills |first=Watson E. |authorlink= |author2=Edgar V. McKnight |author3=Roger Aubrey Bullard |year=1990 |publisher=Mercer University Press |location= |isbn=0-86554-373-9 |page=142 |pages= |accessdate=July 10, 2012 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=goq0VWw9rGIC&lpg=PA142&pg=PA142#v=onepage&q=%22spring%20equinox%22&f=false}}</ref> There is historical evidence that by the middle of the 4th century the Christian churches of the East celebrated the birth and [[Baptism of Jesus]] on the same day, on January 6 while those in the West celebrated a Nativity feast on December 25 (perhaps influenced by the [[Winter solstice]]); and that by the last quarter of the 4th century, the calendars of both churches included both feasts.<ref name=JBurnett >''Aspects of the liturgical year in Cappadocia (325–430)'' by Jill Burnett Comings 2005 {{ISBN|0-8204-7464-9}} pp. 61–71</ref> The earliest suggestions of a fast of Baptism of Jesus on January 6 during the 2nd century comes from [[Clement of Alexandria]], but there is no further mention of such a feast until 361 when [[Emperor Julian]] attended a feast on January 6 in the year 361.<ref name=JBurnett />
In the [[Christian]] tradition the [[Christmastide|Christmas season]] is a period ''beginning'' on [[Christmas Day]] (December 25). In some churches (e.g. the [[Anglican Communion]]) the season continues until the day before the [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]], which is celebrated either on January 6 or on the Sunday between January 2 and 8. In other churches (e.g. the [[Roman Catholic Church]]) it continues until the feast of the [[Baptism of the Lord]], which falls on the Sunday following the Epiphany, or on the Monday following the Epiphany if the Epiphany is moved to January 7 or 8. If the Epiphany is kept on January 6, the [[Church of England]]'s use of the term ''Christmas season'' corresponds to the [[Twelve Days of Christmas]], and ends on [[Twelfth Night (holiday)|Twelfth Night]].
This short Christmas season is preceded by [[Advent]], which begins on the fourth Sunday before Christmas Day: the majority of the secularized Christmas and holiday season falls during Advent. The [[Anglican Communion]] and some Protestant churches follow the Christmas season with an [[Epiphany season]] which lasts until [[Shrove Tuesday]] which is also known as [[Mardi Gras]] or 'Fat Tuesday'. Other European cultures have their own carnival festivities between new year and Lent.
=== Secularisation and commercialisation ===
According to Yanovski et al.,<ref name=weight /> in the United States the holiday season "is generally considered to begin with the day after [[Thanksgiving (United States)|Thanksgiving]] and end after [[New Year's Day]]". According to Axelrad,<ref name=coopers /> the season in the United States encompasses at least Christmas and New Year's Day, and also includes [[Saint Nicholas|Saint Nicholas Day]]. The [[United States Fire Administration|U.S. Fire Administration]]<ref name=USFA>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.usfa.fema.gov/downloads/pdf/publications/fa-236.pdf|title=The Seasonal Nature of Fires|date=January 2005|publisher=U.S. Fire Administration|format=PDF|page=15}}</ref> defines the "Winter Holiday Season" as the period from December 1 to January 7. According to Chen et al.,<ref name=diabetes>{{Cite journal|journal=Diabetes Care|date=February 2004|volume=27|issue=2|pages=326–330|title=A Prospective Study of Glycemic Control During Holiday Time in Type 2 Diabetic Patients|author1=Harn-Shen Chen |author2=Tjin-Shing Jap |author3=Ru-Lin Chen |author4=Hong-Da Lin |pmid=14747208|doi=10.2337/diacare.27.2.326}}</ref> in China the Christmas and holiday season "is generally considered to begin with the [[winter solstice]] and end after the [[Lantern Festival]]". Some stores and shopping malls advertise their Christmas merchandise beginning after [[Halloween]] or even in late October, alongside Halloween items. In the UK and Ireland, Christmas food generally appears on supermarket shelves as early as September or even August, while the Christmas shopping season itself starts from mid November when the high street [[Christmas lights]] are switched on.<ref name=vil/><ref name=gar/>
The precise definition of feasts and festival days that are encompassed by the Christmas and holiday season has become controversial in the United States over recent decades. While in other countries the only holidays included in the "season" are [[Christmas Eve]], Christmas Day, St. Stephen's Day/[[Boxing Day]], [[New Year's Eve]], New Year's Day and [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]], in recent times, this definition in the U.S. has begun to expand to include [[Yule]], [[Hanukkah]], [[Kwanzaa]], [[Thanksgiving (United States)|Thanksgiving]], [[Black Friday (shopping)|Black Friday]] and [[Cyber Monday]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=Lights of Winter: Winter Celebrations Around the World|author1=Heather Conrad |author2=Deforest Walker |publisher=Lightport Books|date=October 1, 2001|isbn=0-9712425-1-8}}</ref> The expansion of the holiday season in the U.S. to encompass Thanksgiving is believed to have begun in the 1920s, when major department stores [[Macy's]] and [[Gimbels]] launched [[Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade|dueling Thanksgiving]] [[6abc Dunkin' Donuts Thanksgiving Day Parade|Day parades]] to promote Christmas sales.<ref name="NewsworksPodcast">{{cite news |url=http://www.newsworks.org/index.php/component/flexicontent/item/30352-pilgrims-and-parades-a-brief-history-of-thanksgiving |title=Pilgrims and parades: A brief history of Thanksgiving |publisher=Newsworks.org (WHYY) |date=November 24, 2011 |accessdate=November 25, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120516160520/http://www.newsworks.org/index.php/component/flexicontent/item/30352-pilgrims-and-parades-a-brief-history-of-thanksgiving |archivedate=May 16, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Due to the phenomenon of [[Christmas creep]] and the informal inclusion of Thanksgiving, the Christmas and holiday season has begun to extend earlier into the year, overlapping [[Veterans Day|Veterans]]/[[Remembrance Day|Remembrance]]/[[Armistice Day]], Halloween and [[Guy Fawkes Night]].
== Shopping == {{further information|Economics of Christmas}} {{Globalize/Northern|date=August 2013}} [[File:Aleksi61wb.jpg|thumb|Holiday shopping in Helsinki, Finland]] The exchange of gifts is central to the Christmas and holiday season, and the season thus also incorporates a "holiday shopping season". This comprises a peak time for the [[retail]] [[Tertiary sector of industry|sector]] at the start of the holiday season (the "Christmas shopping season") and a period of sales at the end of the season, the "January sales".
Although once dedicated mostly to [[white sale]]s and [[Closeout (sale)|clearance sales]], the January sales now comprise both winter close-out sales and sales comprising the redemption of [[gift card]]s given as presents.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Consensus: momentum bodes well for 4Q — Retail sales growth, which began to stir in spring, continue gaining through the beginning of next year|work=DSN Retailing Today|date=October 27, 2003|author=Mike Duff|url=http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0FNP/is_20_42/ai_109665969}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Retailers celebrate "strong" January sales gain of 5.1%|author=Lorrie Grant|work=USA Today |date=February 2, 2006|url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/industries/retail/2006-02-02-jan-sales_x.htm}}</ref> Young-Bean Song, director of analytics at the Atlas Institute in Seattle, states that it is a "myth that the holiday shopping season starts with Thanksgiving and ends with Christmas. January is a key part of the holiday season." stating that for the U.S. e-commerce sector January sales volumes matched December sales volumes in the 2004/2005 Christmas and holiday season.<ref name=Atlas>{{Cite news|title=Atlas: Online Retailers Will Like Mondays During Holidays|author=Mrickey Alam Khan|date=November 10, 2005|url=http://www.dmnews.com/atlas-online-retailers-will-like-mondays-during-holidays/article/893r78/|work=DM News|publisher=Courtenay Communications Corporation}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Many people find this time particularly stressful.<ref name=Times1>{{Cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/newspaper/0,,175-1916654,00.html|work=The Times | location=London|date=December 10, 2005|author=Simon Crompton|title=Ills in the aisles}}</ref> As a remedy, and as a return to what they perceive as the root of Christmas, some practice [[alternative giving]].
=== North America === [[File:King of Prussia Mall second floor near Bloomingdale's at Christmas.jpg|thumb|right|The [[King of Prussia (mall)|King of Prussia]] mall in [[King of Prussia, Pennsylvania]] decorated during the Christmas season]] In the United States, the holiday season is a particularly important time for retail shopping, with shoppers spending more than $600 billion during the 2013 holiday season, averaging about $767 per person. During the 2014 holiday shopping season, retail sales in the United States increased to a total of over $616 billion, and in 2015, retail sales in the United States increased to a total of over $630 billion, up from 2014's $616 billion. The average US holiday shopper spent on average $805. More than half of it was spent on family shopping.<ref>{{cite web|title=Retailers in for a Very Digital Holiday Season, According to NRF Survey|url=https://nrf.com/media/press-releases/retailers-very-digital-holiday-season-according-nrf-survey|website=nrf.com}}</ref>
It is traditionally considered to commence on the day after [[Thanksgiving (United States)|American Thanksgiving]], a Friday colloquially known as either [[Black Friday (shopping)|Black Friday]] or Green Friday. This is widely reputed to be the busiest shopping day of the entire calendar year. However, in 2004 the [[VISA (credit card)|VISA]] credit card organization reported that over the previous several years VISA credit card spending had in fact been 8 to 19 percent higher on the last Saturday before Christmas Day (i.e., [[Super Saturday]]) than on Black Friday.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Consumers Skip Thanksgiving Leftovers and Kick-Off Holiday Shopping with Strong Spending on Black Friday|location=San Francisco|date=November 27, 2004|url=http://usa.visa.com/about_visa/newsroom/press_releases/nr244.html|work=Press releases|publisher=VISA U.S.A.}}</ref> A survey conducted in 2005 by [[GfK NOP]] discovered that "Americans aren't as drawn to Black Friday as many retailers may think", with only 17% of those polled saying that they will begin holiday shopping immediately after Thanksgiving, 13% saying that they plan to finish their shopping before November 24 and 10% waiting until the very last day before performing their holiday gift shopping.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mirrorgeek.com/consumers-tighten-their-purse-strings-this-holiday-season-fuel-costs-putting-a-damper-on-shopping-plans.html|publisher=Mirror Geek|title=Consumers Tighten Their Purse Strings This Holiday Season – Fuel Costs Putting a Damper on Shopping Plans}}</ref>
[[File:North Pole dancer SSSP jeh.JPG|thumb|left|Public, secular celebration in seasonal costume]] According to a survey by the Canadian Toy Association, peak sales in the toy industry occur in the Christmas and holiday season, but this peak has been occurring later and later in the season every year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://commercecan.ic.gc.ca/scdt/bizmap/interface2.nsf/vDownload/IMI_3442/$file/X_1970281.DOC |format=Microsoft Word |publisher=U.S. Commercial Service in Canada |title=report }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
[[File:The_Rocket_Garden_during_Christmas.jpg|thumb|right|Christmas at the NASA [[Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex]]]]
In 2005, the kick-off to the Christmas and holiday season for [[online shopping]], the first Monday after US Thanksgiving, was named [[Cyber Monday]]. Although it was a peak, that was not the busiest on-line shopping day of that year. The busiest on-line shopping days were December 12 and 13, almost two weeks later; the second Monday in December has since become known as [[Green Monday]]. Another notable day is Free Shipping Day, a promotional day that serves as the last day in which a person can order a good online and have it arrive via standard shipping (the price of which the sender pays) prior to Christmas Eve; this day is usually on or near December 16.<ref name=tc2011>[https://techcrunch.com/2011/12/18/green-monday-and-free-shipping-day-help-boost-online-holiday-sales-by-15-percent-to-31b/ Green Monday And Free Shipping Day Help Boost Online Holiday Sales By 15 Percent To $31B]. ''TechCrunch.com''. Retrieved December 18, 2011.</ref> Four of the largest 11 on-line shopping days in 2005 were December 11 to 16, with an increase of 12% over 2004 figures.<ref>{{cite web|title=Holiday Sales Tune-up: Simple, effective tactics to increase seasonal sales|format=PDF|url=http://lenser.com/graphics/holiday_tuneup.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080911010412/http://lenser.com/graphics/holiday_tuneup.pdf |archivedate=September 11, 2008 |date=October 24, 2006|publisher=MarketLive, Inc.}} – This in turn cites the 2006 Holiday Best Practices Report by Shop.org.</ref> In 2011, Cyber Monday was slightly busier than Green Monday and Free Shipping Day, although all three days registered sales of over US$1 billion, and all three days registered gains ranging from 14% to 22% over the previous year.<ref name=tc2011/> Analysts had predicted the peak on December 12, noting that Mondays are the most popular days for on-line shopping during the holiday shopping season, in contrast to the middle of the week during the rest of the year. They attribute this to people "shopping in stores and malls on the weekends, and [...] extending that shopping experience when they get into work on Monday" by "looking for deals, [...] comparison shopping and [...] finding items that were out of stock in the stores".<ref name=Atlas />
In 2006, the average US household was expected to spend about $1,700 on Christmas and holiday spendings.<ref name=Economist1>{{Cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/8336489?story_id=8336489|work=The Economist |title=Let the shopping begin|date=November 24, 2006}}</ref> Retail strategists such as ICSC Research<ref>{{cite web|title=2005 U.S. Holiday Spending Outlook|date=October 18, 2005|work=ICSC Research|publisher=Los Alamos Chamber of Commerce|page=3|url=http://www.losalamoschamber.com/lachamber/downloads/uploaded_files/default/Holidayforecast.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080227124307/http://www.losalamoschamber.com/lachamber/downloads/uploaded_files/default/Holidayforecast.pdf|archivedate=February 27, 2008|format=PDF}}</ref> observed in 2005 that 15% of holiday expenditures were in the form of gift certificates, a percentage that was rising. So they recommended that retailers manage their inventories for the entire holiday shopping season, with a leaner inventory at the start and new winter merchandise for the January sales.
Michael P. Niemira, chief economist and director of research for the Shopping Center Council, states that he expects gift certificate usage to be between US$30billion and US$40billion in the 2006/2007 holiday shopping season. On the basis of the growing popularity of gift certificates, he states that "To get a true picture of holiday sales, one may consider measuring October, November, December and January sales combined as opposed to just November and December sales.", because with "a hefty amount of that spending not hitting the books until January, extending the length of the season makes sense".<ref>{{Cite news|title=Extended holiday shopping season bodes well|work=East Bay Business Times|date=November 17, 2006|author=Dave Goll|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/eastbay/stories/2006/11/20/story3.html?page=1&b=1163998800^1378052}}</ref>
According to the Deloitte 2007 Holiday Survey,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.deloitte.com/dtt/press_release/0,1014,cid%253D177262,00.html?wt.mc_id=w |date=November 1, 2007 |title=Press Release:Yes, Virginia, There is a Santa Claus; Gift Buying is Expected to Hold Steady, Although Consumers Will Spend Less Overall |publisher=Deloitte }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> for the fourth straight year, [[gift card]]s are expected to be the top gift purchase in 2007, with more than two-thirds (69 percent) of consumers surveyed planning to buy them, compared with 66 percent in 2006. In addition, holiday shoppers are planning to buy even more cards this year: an average of 5.5 cards, compared with the 4.6 cards they planned to buy last year. One in six consumers (16 percent) plan to buy 10 or more cards, compared with 11 percent last year. Consumers are also spending more in total on gift cards and more per card: $36.25 per card on average compared with $30.22 last year. Gift cards continue to grow in acceptance: Almost four in 10 consumers surveyed (39 percent) would rather get a gift card than merchandise, an increase from last year’s 35 percent. Also, resistance to giving gift cards continues to decline: 19 percent say they don’t like to give gift cards because they’re too impersonal (down from 22 percent last year). Consumers said that the cards are popular gifts for adults, teens and children alike, and almost half (46 percent) intend to buy them for immediate family; however, they are hesitant to buy them for spouses or significant others, with only 14 percent saying they plan to buy them for those recipients.
Some stores in Canada hold [[Boxing Week]] sales (before the end of the year) for [[income tax]] purposes.
==== Christmas creep ==== {{Main article|Christmas creep}} What has become known as "Christmas creep" refers to a [[merchandising]] phenomenon in which merchants and retailers exploit the commercialized status of [[Christmas]] by moving up the start of the holiday shopping season.<ref name="titleChicago Sun-Times:: Search">{{Cite web|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=CSTB&p_theme=cstb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB36D9911BB108A&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |title=He's well-suited to enjoying life of Santa | first = Alf | last = Siewers |accessdate=December 26, 2007 | date = November 25, 1987 |format= |work=Chicago Sun-Times| quote = And so does the culture, with a commercializing of himself that Santa deplores even as he has watched the holiday season creep back to Labor Day.}}</ref> The term was first used in the mid-1980s,<ref name="Macmillan">{{Cite web |url=http://www.macmillandictionary.com/New-Words/060918-Christmas-creep.htm |title=Macmillan English Dictionary Word of the Week Archive – "Christmas creep" |accessdate=December 26, 2007 |date=September 18, 2006 |publisher=Macmillan Publishers |first=Kerry |last=Maxwell |work=New Words |quote=The term Christmas creep was first used in the mid-eighties, though gained wider recognition more recently, possibly due to subsequent coinage of the expression mission creep. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070320172802/http://www.macmillandictionary.com/New-Words/060918-Christmas-creep.htm |archivedate=March 20, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> and is associated with a desire of merchants to take advantage of particularly heavy Christmas-related shopping well before [[Black Friday (shopping)|Black Friday]] in the United States and before [[Halloween]] in Canada.
The term is not used in the UK and Ireland, where retailers call Christmas the "golden quarter", that is, the three months of October through December is the quarter of the year in which the retail industry hopes to make the most profit.<ref name="guardian.co.uk">Zoe Wood (Tuesday December 21, 2010) [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/dec/21/uk-snow-chaos-christmas-dinners Snow chaos raises fears for Christmas dinners minus the trimmings] ''[[The Guardian]]''</ref> It can apply for other holidays as well, notably [[Valentine's Day]], Easter and [[Mother's Day]].
=== Europe === In the Republic of Ireland and the United Kingdom, the Christmas shopping season starts from mid-November, around the time when [[high street]] [[Christmas lights]] are turned on.<ref name=vil>[http://www.viewlondon.co.uk/whatson/south-molton-street-christmas-lights-feature-event-4279.html South Molton and Brook Street Christmas Lights] (Tuesday November 16, 2010) ''View London.co.uk''</ref><ref name=gar>Julia Kollewe Monday (November 29, 2010) [https://www.theguardian.com/business/2010/nov/29/christmas-shopping-spree-starts West End spree worth £250m marks start of Christmas shopping season] ''[[The Guardian]]''</ref> In the UK in 2010, up to £8 billion was expected to be spent online at Christmas, approximately a quarter of total retail festive sales.<ref name=gar/> Retailers in the UK call Christmas the "golden quarter", that is, the three months of October to December is the quarter of the year in which the retail industry hopes to make the most money.<ref name="guardian.co.uk"/> In Ireland, around early December or late November each year, [[The Late Late Toy Show]] is broadcast on Irish television, which features all the popular toys throughout the year being demonstrated and showcased before the holiday season and shopping sprees commence.
The Netherlands and Belgium have a double holiday. The first one, the arrival of the Bishop Saint Nicholas and Black Peter, starts about mid November, with presents being given on December 5 or 6. This is a separate holiday from Christmas, Bishop Saint Nick (Sinterklaas) and Santa Claus (Kerstman) being different people. Netherlands and Belgium often do not start the Christmas season until December 6 or 7, i.e. after [[Sinterklaas]] has finished.
In France, the January sales are restricted by legislation to no more than four weeks in [[Paris]], and no more than six weeks for the rest of the country, usually beginning on the first Wednesday in January, and are one of only two periods of the year when retailers are permitted to hold sales.<ref name=Times2>{{Cite news|url=http://travel.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,10290-1900656_2,00.html|work=The Sunday Times Online | location=London|date=December 4, 2005|title=An international guide to the January sales|first1=Joanna|last1=Sugden|first2=Adam|last2=Fresco}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.foodanddrinkeurope.com/Retail/French-store-sales-rise-in-January|date=February 7, 2003|title=French store sales rise in January|work=Food and Drink Europe|publisher=Decision News Media SAS|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110807170107/http://www.foodanddrinkeurope.com/Retail/French-store-sales-rise-in-January|archivedate=August 7, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In Italy, the January sales begin on the first weekend in January, and last for at least six weeks.<ref name=Times2 />
In Croatia and Bosnia (predominantly Sarajevo) the sales periods are regulated by the Consumer Protection Act. The January sales period starts on December 27 and can last up to 60 days.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nacional.hr/sezonska-snizenja-dva-puta-godisnje-zimsko-pocinje-27-prosinca/|title=Sezonska sniženja dva puta godišnje, zimsko počinje 27. prosinca|author=HINA|date=|work=nacional.hr|accessdate=January 13, 2016}}</ref>
In Germany, the ''Winterschlussverkauf'' (winter sale before the season ends) was one of two official sales periods (the other being the ''Sommerschlussverkauf'', the summer sales). It begins on the last Monday in January and lasts for 12 days, selling left-over goods from the holiday shopping season, as well as the winter collections. However, unofficially, goods are sold at reduced prices by many stores throughout the whole of January. By the time the sales officially begin the only goods left on sale are low-quality ones, often specially manufactured for the sales.<ref>{{cite book|title=Fulbright Primer|publisher=Fulbright Commission in Berlin|format=PDF|url=http://www.fulbright.de/togermany/resources/primer.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060831075103/http://www.fulbright.de/togermany/resources/primer.pdf|archivedate=August 31, 2006|date=March 20, 2002|chapter=Shopping|page=44}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Going Shopping|chapter=Opening hours in German-speaking countries|work=Exeter University Beginners' German|author=Paul Joyce|year=2005|url=http://userweb.port.ac.uk/~joyce1/abinitio/chap9-16.html|publisher=[[University of Exeter]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101223050550/http://userweb.port.ac.uk/~joyce1/abinitio/chap9-16.html|archivedate=December 23, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Since a legislative reform to the corresponding law in 2004,<ref name="nichtamtliches Inhaltsverzeichnis">{{cite web | title=UWG | website=nichtamtliches Inhaltsverzeichnis | url=http://www.gesetze-im-internet.de/uwg_2004/index.html | language=de | access-date=2017-12-10}}</ref> season sales are now allowed over the whole year and are no longer restricted to season-related goods. However, voluntary sales still called "Winterschlussverkauf" take place further on in most stores at the same time every year.
In Sweden, where the week of the [[Advent Sunday|first Advent Sunday]] marks the official start of the Christmas and holiday season, continuing with [[Saint Lucy's Day]] on December 13, followed up by [[Christmas]] before the ''Mellandagsrea'' (between days sell off) traditionally begins on December 27 (nowadays often December 26 or even December 25) and lasts during the rest of the Christmas holiday. It is similar to [[Black Friday (shopping)|Black Friday]], but lasts longer. They last 34–35 days. Black Friday itself has also gained publicity in Sweden since the early-2010s. The Swedish Christmas and holiday season continues over [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]], and finally ends on [[St. Knut's Day]] when the children have a [[Knut's party]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yourlivingcity.com/stockholm/cultural/events/julgransplundring/|title=Julgransplundring: Rocking around the Christmas Tree|publisher=Your Living City|language=|date=January 3, 2014|accessdate=November 21, 2015}}</ref>
In Bosnia (Republika Srpska), Montenegro and Serbia, holiday sales starts in the middle of December and last for at least one month.
===Asia=== Hong Kong, China has a lot of seasonal activities and traditions to offer around Christmas time. [[Public holidays in Hong Kong|December 25 and 26 are Public Holidays]] that makes most shops open for shopping. Locals and tourists love to watch the 30-meter Swarovski Christmas tree in the Central as well as the Christmas light displays on buildings on Victoria Harbour.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Top 10 places to spend your Christmas|url = http://edition.cnn.com/2010/TRAVEL/12/10/top.christmas.places/index.html|website = edition.cnn.com|accessdate = October 12, 2015}}</ref> A huge party in Hong Kong called [[Hong Kong New Year Countdown Celebrations|Winterfest]] is celebrated every year which involves malls, shops, theme parks and other attractions.
The Philippines has the longest [[Christmas in the Philippines|Christmas season]], reportedly.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Philippines shows the world how to celebrate Christmas - CNN.com|url = http://www.cnn.com/2012/12/05/world/asia/irpt-xmas-philippines-traditions/index.html|website = CNN|accessdate = October 12, 2015}}</ref> As early as September up until January 9, which is the feast of the [[Black Nazarene]] (the season ends on the Feast of the Lord's Baptism on the 2nd Sunday of January or the Monday after Epiphany if the 2nd Sunday is marked as such), Carolers can be typically heard going door to door serenading fellow Filipinos in exchange of money. All over the entire country, [[parol]]s (star shaped lanterns) are hung everywhere and lights are lit. [[Simbang Gabi]] or dawn masses start December 16 and run for nine days up until Christmas Eve.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Five Christmas holiday locations in Asia {{!}} Asian Correspondent|url = http://asiancorrespondent.com/115604/five-christmas-holiday-locations-in-asia/|website = asiancorrespondent.com|accessdate = October 12, 2015}}</ref>
South Korea's population are 30% Christian<ref>{{Cite web|title = 6 facts about South Korea's growing Christian population|url = http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2014/08/12/6-facts-about-christianity-in-south-korea/|website = Pew Research Center|accessdate = October 13, 2015}}</ref> and Christmas is a [[Public holidays in South Korea|Public Holiday]]. According to the [[The Washington Post|''Washington Post'']], "Koreans prefer cash Christmas gifts over more creative presents."<!--I remember that it was a marketing gimmick from some company: Santa Claus sometimes wears blue instead of the traditional red.--><ref>{{Cite news|title = 10 foreign Christmas traditions that Americans might want to adopt|url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2014/12/24/10-foreign-christmas-traditions-that-americans-might-want-to-adopt/|newspaper = The Washington Post|date = December 24, 2014|access-date = October 12, 2015|issn = 0190-8286|first = Rick|last = Noack}}</ref>
Singapore widely celebrates Christmas which is a [[Public holidays in Singapore|Public Holiday]] in this country. For six weeks, mid-November to early January, the {{convert|2.2|km|adj=on}} stretch of [[Orchard Road]] glitters with lights from decorated trees and building facades of malls and hotels.
== Greetings == {{redirect|Happy New Year}} {{Redirect|Christmas Greetings|the Bing Crosby album|Christmas Greetings (album)}}
A selection of goodwill greetings are often used around the world to address strangers, family, colleagues or friends during the season. Some greetings are more prevalent than others, depending on culture and location. Traditionally, the predominant greetings of the season have been "Merry Christmas", "Happy Christmas", and "Happy New Year". In the mid-to-late 20th century in the United States, more generic greetings such as "Happy Holidays" and "Season's Greetings" began to rise in cultural prominence, and this would later spread to other Western countries including Canada, Australia and to a lesser extent some European countries. A 2012 poll by [[Rasmussen Reports]] indicated that 68% of Americans prefer the use of "Merry Christmas", while 23% preferred "Happy Holidays".<ref name="RRpoll" /> A similarly-timed Canadian poll conducted by [[Ipsos-Reid]] indicated that 72% of Canadians preferred "Merry Christmas".<ref name="Canadapoll" />
=== Merry Christmas and Happy Christmas === {{redirect-multi|2|Merry Christmas|Happy Christmas}}
The greetings and farewells "Merry Christmas" and "Happy Christmas" are traditionally used in English-speaking countries, starting a few weeks before Christmas (December 25) each year.
Variations are: * "Merry Christmas", the traditional English greeting, composed of [[wikt:merry|merry]] (''jolly, happy'') and Christmas ([[Old English]]: ''Cristes mæsse,'' for ''Christ's Mass''). * "Happy Christmas", an equivalent greeting that is common in Great Britain and Ireland. * "Merry Xmas", with the "X" replacing "Christ" (''see [[Xmas]]'') is sometimes used in writing, but very rarely in speech. This is in line with the traditional use of the Greek letter [[chi (letter)|chi]] ([[uppercase]] Χ, [[lowercase]] χ), the initial letter of the word [[wikt:Χριστός|Χριστός]] (Christ), to refer to Christ.
[[File:Christmas cake, Boxing Day 2008.jpg|thumb|A [[Christmas cake]] with a "Merry Christmas" greeting]] These greetings and their equivalents in other languages are popular not only in countries with large Christian populations but also in the largely non-Christian nations of China and Japan, where Christmas is celebrated primarily due to cultural influences of predominantly Christian countries. They have somewhat decreased in popularity in the United States and Canada in recent decades, but polls in 2005 indicated that they remained more popular than "Happy Holidays" or other alternatives.<ref name="preferMC">{{cite web | year = 2005 | url = http://businessknowledgesource.com/blog/merry_christmas_beats_happy_holidays_in_actual_2005_consumer_usage_021216.html | title = Merry Christmas beats "Happy Holidays" In 2005 Usage | work = | publisher = BusinessKnowledgeSource.com | accessdate = June 12, 2006}}</ref>
==== History of the phrase ==== [[Image:Firstchristmascard.jpg|thumb|left|"Merry Christmas" appears on the world's first commercially produced Christmas card, designed by [[John Callcott Horsley]] for [[Henry Cole]] in 1843]] "Merry," derived from the [[Old English]] ''myrige'', originally meant merely "pleasant, agreeable" rather than joyous or jolly (as in the phrase "merry month of May").<ref name=AFP/> Christmas has been celebrated since the 4th century AD, the first known usage of any Christmas greeting dates was in 1534.<ref>{{cite web|title=Merry|url=http://www.oed.com/view/Entry/116864?redirectedFrom=Merry+Christmas#eid37352934|website=Oxford English Dictionary|accessdate=January 15, 2017}} {{subscription}}</ref> "''Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year''" (thus incorporating two greetings) was in an informal letter written by an English admiral in 1699. The same phrase is contained in the title of the English [[carol (music)|carol]] "[[We Wish You a Merry Christmas]]," and also appears in the first commercial [[Christmas card#History|Christmas card]], produced by [[Henry Cole]] in England in 1843.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/1679110.stm "Christmas card sold for record price"]. BBC News. Retrieved December 25, 2017</ref>
Also in 1843, [[Charles Dickens]]' ''[[A Christmas Carol]]'' was published, during the mid Victorian revival of the holiday. The word Merry was then beginning to take on its current meaning of "jovial, cheerful, jolly and outgoing".<ref name=AFP>{{cite web | year = 2004 |author=Gary Martin | url = http://www.phrases.org.uk/meanings/merry-christmas.html| title = Holiday Greetings, Merry Christmas | publisher = The Phrase Finder | accessdate = June 11, 2006}}</ref> "''Merry Christmas''" in this new context figured prominently in ''A Christmas Carol''. The cynical [[Ebenezer Scrooge]] rudely deflects the friendly greeting: "If I could work my will … every idiot who goes about with 'Merry Christmas' on his lips should be boiled with his own [[Christmas pudding|pudding]]."<ref>{{cite news | title = Dickens' classic 'Christmas Carol' still sings to us| url = https://www.usatoday.com/life/books/news/2008-12-17-dickens-main_N.htm| publisher = ''[[USA Today]]''| accessdate =May 4, 2010| first=Bob| last=Minzesheimer| date=December 22, 2008}}</ref> After the visit from the Ghosts of Christmas effects his transformation, Scrooge exclaims; "I am as merry as a school-boy. A merry Christmas to everybody!" and heartily exchanges the wish to all he meets.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f8ANAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA58&dq=A+merry+Christmas+to+us+all,+my+dears.+God+bless+us!%22#v=onepage&q=A%20merry%20Christmas%20to%20us%20all%2C%20my%20dears.%20God%20bless%20us!%22&f=false |title=A Christmas carol: in prose : being a ghost story of Christmas|first= Charles|last= Dickens |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=December 25, 2012}}</ref> The instant popularity of ''A Christmas Carol'', the [[Victorian era]] Christmas traditions it typifies, and the term's new meaning appearing in the book popularized the phrase "Merry Christmas".<ref>Joe L. Wheeler. ''Christmas in my heart,'' Volume 10. p.97. Review and Herald Pub Assoc, 2001. {{ISBN|0-8280-1622-4}}</ref><ref>Robertson Cochrane. Wordplay: origins, meanings, and usage of the English language. p.126 [[University of Toronto Press]], 1996 {{ISBN|0-8020-7752-8}}</ref>
The alternative "Happy Christmas" gained usage in the late 19th century, and in the UK and Ireland is a common spoken greeting, along with "Merry Christmas". One reason may be the Victorian middle class influence in attempting to separate wholesome celebration of the Christmas season from public insobriety and associated asocial behaviour, at a time when ''merry'' also meant "intoxicated" – [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|Queen Elizabeth II]] is said to prefer "Happy Christmas" for this reason.<ref name=AFP/> In her annual [[Royal Christmas Message|Christmas message]]s to the Commonwealth, Queen Elizabeth has used "happy Christmas" far more often than "merry Christmas".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royal.gov.uk/ImagesandBroadcasts/TheQueensChristmasBroadcasts/ChristmasBroadcasts/ChristmasBroadcast1952.aspx |title=The Queen's First Christmas Broadcast 1952 |publisher=The Royal Household |accessdate=December 13, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160117103730/http://www.royal.gov.uk/ImagesandBroadcasts/TheQueensChristmasBroadcasts/ChristmasBroadcasts/ChristmasBroadcast1952.aspx |archivedate=January 17, 2016 }} Note: [http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&num=100&q=site%3Awww.royal.gov.uk%2FImagesandBroadcasts%2FTheQueensChristmasBroadcasts%2FChristmasBroadcasts%2F+%22merry+Christmas%22 "Merry Christmas"] has been used only four times: in 1962, 1967, 1970 and 1999. "Happy Christmas" has been used on almost every broadcast since 1956. One year included [http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&num=100&q=site%3Awww.royal.gov.uk%2FImagesandBroadcasts%2FTheQueensChristmasBroadcasts%2FChristmasBroadcasts%2F+%22merry+Christmas%22+%22happy+Christmas%22 both greetings]. (note [http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&num=100&q=site%3Awww.royal.gov.uk%2FImagesandBroadcasts%2FTheQueensChristmasBroadcasts%2FChristmasBroadcasts%2F+%22blessed+Christmas%22 "blessed Christmas"] in 1954 and 2007)</ref>
In the American poet [[Clement Moore]]'s "[[A Visit from St. Nicholas]]" (1823), the final line, originally written as "Happy Christmas to all, and to all a good night", has been changed in many later editions to "Merry Christmas to all", perhaps indicating the relative popularity of the phrases in the US.
===Happy Holidays=== {{redirect|Happy Holidays|other meanings of "Happy Holidays"|Happy Holidays (disambiguation)}}
In the United States, "Happy Holidays" (along with the similarly generalized "Season's Greetings") has become a common holiday greeting in the public sphere of department stores, public schools and greeting cards. Its use is generally confined to the period between [[Thanksgiving (United States)|United States Thanksgiving]] and New Year's Day.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}} The phrase "Happy Holidays" has been used as a Christmas greeting in the United States for more than 100 years.<ref name="Stack">{{cite news|last1=Stack|first1=Liam|title=How the ‘War on Christmas’ Controversy Was Created|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/19/us/war-on-christmas-controversy.html?_r=0|work=The New York Times|date=December 19, 2016}}</ref>
The increasing usage of "Happy Holidays" has been the subject of some [[Christmas controversy|controversy in the United States]]. Advocates claim that "Happy Holidays" is an inclusive greeting that is not intended as an attack on Christianity or other religions, but is rather a response to what they say is the reality of a growing non-Christian population.
Critics of "Happy Holidays" generally claim it is a secular [[neologism]]. The greeting may be deemed materialistic, consumerist, atheistic, indifferentist, agnostic, [[politically correct]] and/or [[anti-Christianity]]. Critics of the phrase have associated it with a larger cultural clash termed the "[[War on Christmas]]".<ref name="Stack"/><ref>{{cite web |year = 2004 |url = http://www.reason.com/news/show/32013.html |title = Why "Happy Holidays"? |work = |publisher = Reason Magazine |accessdate = June 29, 2008}}</ref>
===Season's Greetings=== {{redirect|Season's Greetings|other meanings of "Season's Greetings"|Season's Greetings (disambiguation)}}
"Season's Greetings" is a greeting more commonly used as a motto on winter season [[greeting card]]s, and in commercial advertisements, than as a spoken phrase. In addition to "Merry Christmas", Victorian Christmas cards bore a variety of salutations, including "Compliments of the Season" and "Christmas Greetings." By the late 19th century, "With the Season's Greetings" or simply "The Season's Greetings" began appearing. By the 1920s it had been shortened to "Season's Greetings",<ref>{{cite web | year = 2005 | url = http://www.antiquesandthearts.com/TT-2005-11-15-12-06-16p1.htm | title = Maryland Historical Society Library Devotes Exhibit To Holiday Cards | publisher = Antiques and the Arts Online | accessdate = June 29, 2008 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080418094137/http://antiquesandthearts.com/TT-2005-11-15-12-06-16p1.htm | archivedate = April 18, 2008 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> and has been a greeting card fixture ever since. Several [[White House]] Christmas cards, including U.S. President [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]]'s 1955 card, have featured the phrase.<ref>{{cite web | year = | url = http://www.whitehouse.gov/president/holiday/cards/06.html | title = Season's Greetings from the White House | work = | publisher = The White House | accessdate = June 29, 2008 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080725105458/http://www.whitehouse.gov/president/holiday/cards/06.html | archivedate = July 25, 2008 | df = mdy-all }}</ref>
== Medical analyses == Various studies have been performed on the effects of the Christmas and holiday season, which encompasses several [[feast day]]s, on health. They have concluded that the health changes that occur during the Christmas and holiday season are not reversed during the rest of the year and have a long-term cumulative effect over a person's life, and that the risks of several medical problems increase during the Christmas and holiday season.
=== Nutrition === Yanovski et al.<ref name=weight /> investigated the assertion that the average American gains weight over the season. They found that average weight gain over the Christmas and holiday season is around {{convert|0.48|kg}}. They also found that this weight gain is not reversed over the rest of the year, and concluded that this "probably contributes to the increase in body weight that frequently occurs during adulthood" (cf [[Lent]]).
Chan et al.<ref name=diabetes /> investigated the increases in A1C and fasting plasma glucose in [[diabetes mellitus type 2|type 2 diabetic patients]], to see whether these increases were steady throughout the year or varied seasonally. They concluded that the winter holidays did influence the glycemic control of the patients, with the largest increases being during that period, increases that "might not be reversed during the summer and autumn months".
The Christmas and holiday season, according to a survey by the ADA, is the second most popular reason, after birthdays, for sharing food in the workplace. The [[British Columbia Safety Council]] states that if proper food safety procedures are not followed, food set out for sharing in the workplace can serve as a breeding ground for bacteria, and recommends that perishable foods (for which it gives pizza, cold cuts, dips, salads, and sandwiches as examples) should not sit out for more than 2 hours.<ref>{{cite web|format=PDF|publisher=British Columbia Safety Council|title=Safety First|date=Spring 2006|url=http://www.safetycouncil.bc.ca/newsletter/2006/spring/pdfs/givebacteriathepinkslip.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080227124307/http://www.safetycouncil.bc.ca/newsletter/2006/spring/pdfs/givebacteriathepinkslip.pdf|archivedate=February 27, 2008}}</ref>
=== Other issues === A survey conducted in 2005 found shopping caused headaches in nearly a quarter of people and sleeplessness in 11 percent.<ref name=Times1 />
Phillips et al.<ref name=cardiac>{{Cite journal|title=Cardiac Mortality Is Higher Around Christmas and New Year's Than at Any Other Time|author1=David P. Phillips |author2=Jason R. Jarvinen |author3=Ian S. Abramson |author4=Rosalie R. Phillips |journal=Circulation|date=September 10, 2004|volume=110|pages=3781–3788|doi=10.1161/01.CIR.0000151424.02045.F7|url=http://weber.ucsd.edu/~dphillip/circulation_journal_holiday_heart_final_print_version.pdf|format=PDF|pmid=15596560|issue=25}}</ref> investigated whether some or all of the spike in cardiac mortality that occurs during December and January could be ascribed to the Christmas/New Year's holidays rather than to climatic factors. They concluded that the Christmas and holiday season is "a risk factor for cardiac and noncardiac mortality", stating that there are "multiple explanations for this association, including the possibility that holiday-induced delays in seeking treatment play a role in producing the twin holiday spikes".
The Asthma Society of Canada<ref name=ASC>{{cite web|author=Michael Gallinger|publisher=Asthma Society of Canada|date=November 28, 2005|url=http://asthma.ca/corp/services/pdf/asthma_winter_holiday_season_tips_eng.pdf|format=PDF|title=Christmas and holiday season Tips}}</ref> states that the Christmas and holiday season increases exposure to irritants because people spend 90% of their time indoors, and that seasonal decorations in the home introduce additional, further, irritants beyond the ones that exist all year around. It recommends that asthmatics avoid scented candles, for example, recommending either that candles not be lit or that soy or beeswax candles be employed.
== Other effects == According to the Stanford Recycling Center<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Stanford Recycling Center|url=http://recycling.stanford.edu/5r/holidays.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100707130217/http://recycling.stanford.edu/5r/holidays.html |archivedate=July 7, 2010 |title=Tips for a "Green" Holiday Season}}</ref> Americans throw away 25% more trash during the Christmas and holiday season than at other times of the year.
Because of the cold weather in the Northern Hemisphere, the Christmas and holiday season (as well as the second half of winter) is a time of increased use of fuel for domestic heating. This has prompted concerns in the United Kingdom about the possibility of a shortage in the domestic [[natural gas|gas]] supply. However, in the event of an exceptionally long cold season, it is industrial users, signed on to interruptible supply contracts, who would find themselves without gas supply.<ref>{{Cite news|work=The Times | location=London|date=December 29, 2005|title=Thousands shiver as gas boiler failures double|author=Peter Klinger|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,9558-1961817,00.html}}</ref>
The U.S. Fire Administration<ref name=USFA /> states that the Christmas and holiday season is "a time of elevated risk for winter heating fires" and that the fact that many people celebrate the different holidays during the Christmas and holiday season by decorating their homes with seasonal garlands, electric lights, candles, and banners, has the potential to change the profile of fire incidence and cause. The Government of Alberta Ministry of Municipal Affairs<ref name=AMA>{{cite web|format=PDF|publisher=Government of Alberta Ministry of Municipal Affairs|url=http://www.municipalaffairs.gov.ab.ca/ss/safety_tip_sheets/candles.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070508142908/http://www.municipalaffairs.gov.ab.ca/ss/safety_tip_sheets/candles.pdf |archivedate=May 8, 2007 |title=Candle Saafety Tips|date=April 8, 2003}}</ref> states that candle-related fires rise by 140% during the Christmas and holiday season, with most fires involving human error and most deaths and injuries resulting from the failure to extinguish candles before going to bed. It states that consumers don't expect candle holders to tip over or to catch fire, assuming that they are safe, but that in fact candle holders can do this.
Because of increased alcohol consumption at festivities and poorer road conditions during the winter months, alcohol-related road traffic accidents increase over the Christmas and holiday season.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Controlled drinking experiment teaches valuable lesson|author=Kelly Grinsteinner|work=The Daily Tribune|date=November 28, 2005|url=http://www.hibbingmn.com/dailytribune/index.php?sect_rank=1&story_id=207592|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080223112702/http://www.hibbingmn.com/dailytribune/index.php?sect_rank=1&story_id=207592|archivedate=February 23, 2008}}</ref>
== Legal issues == {{Expand section|date=June 2008}}
=== United States === {{main article|County of Allegheny v. American Civil Liberties Union|Establishment Clause}}
In the United States, the [[Establishment Clause of the First Amendment]] to the [[Constitution of the United States]] has had significant legal impact upon the activities of governments and of state-funded [[Public school (government funded)|public school]]s during and relating to the Christmas and holiday season, and has been the source of controversy.
Public schools are subject to what the [[Anti-Defamation League]] terms the "December Dilemma",<ref>{{cite web|title=The "December Dilemma": December Holiday Guidelines for Public Schools|work=Religion in America's Public Square: Crossing the Line?|author=Abraham H. Foxman|publisher=Anti-Defamation League|url=http://www.adl.org/religious_freedom/resource_kit/december_holiday_guidelines.asp|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060831001009/http://www.adl.org/religious_freedom/resource_kit/december_holiday_guidelines.asp|archivedate=August 31, 2006|df=mdy-all}}</ref> namely the task of "acknowledging the various religious and secular holiday traditions celebrated during that time of year" whilst restricting observances of the various religious festivals to what is constitutionally permissible. The ADL and many school district authorities have published guidelines for schools and for teachers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Religion in the Public Schools: Teaching About Religious Holidays|publisher=Anti-Defamation League|url=http://www.adl.org/religion_ps_2004/teaching.asp|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060831084018/http://www.adl.org/religion_ps_2004/teaching.asp|archivedate=August 31, 2006|df=mdy-all}}</ref> For example: The directive on maintaining religious neutrality in public schools over the Christmas and holiday season, given to public school administrators in the [[District of Columbia]] by the Superintendent,<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.k12.dc.us/dcps/policies/religion.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080227124307/http://www.k12.dc.us/dcps/policies/religion.pdf|archivedate=February 27, 2008|format=PDF|author=Paul L. Vance|date=December 14, 2001|title=Religious Neutrality Requirements}}</ref> contains several points on what may and may not be taught in the D.C. school district, the themes of parties and concerts, the uses of religious symbols, the locations of school events and classes and prayer.
=== Russia === In 2002, for the Christmas and holiday season, [[Moscow]] mayor [[Yuriy Luzhkov]] ordered all stores, restaurants, cafés and markets to display seasonal decorations and lights in their windows and interiors from December 1 onwards. Banks, post offices and public institutions were to do the same from December 15, with violators liable for fines of up to 200 rubles. Every business was ordered to have illuminated windows during the hours of 16:30 until 01:00. This caused a mixed reaction, with people objecting to being forced to put up decorations.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Moscow To Pay a Price for Not Celebrating|author1=Oksana Yablokova |author2=Kevin O'Flynn |work=The [[St. Petersburg Times (Russia)|St. Petersburg Times]]|date=November 29, 2002|url=http://www.sptimes.ru/index.php?action_id=2&story_id=8711}}</ref>
== See also == {{portal|Christmas|Holidays}} * [[Happy Holiday (song)]] * [[List of winter festivals]] * [[Seasonal affective disorder]] * [[Winterval]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== Further reading == * {{Cite book|title=Consumer rites: the buying & selling of American holidays|author=Leigh Eric Schmidt|location=Princeton, N.J.|publisher=Princeton University Press|date=September 1, 1995|isbn=0-691-02980-6|pages=106–191}} * {{cite web|title=Holiday Shopping? How To Be on Guard When You're Online|publisher=[[Federal Trade Commission]]|work=Consumer Alerts|url=http://www.ftc.gov/bcp/conline/pubs/alerts/shopalrt.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070329075928/http://www.ftc.gov/bcp/conline/pubs/alerts/shopalrt.htm |archivedate=March 29, 2007 }} – The FTC's advice to consumers who are shopping during the holiday season * {{Cite journal|journal=The Colorado Lawyer|date=December 2002|volume=31|issue=12|page=139|title=Bah Humbug! Colorado Law and the Christmas and holiday season|author=Tom I. Romero II|url=http://www.cobar.org/tcl/tcl_articles.cfm?ArticleID=2056|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050906024725/http://www.cobar.org/tcl/tcl_articles.cfm?ArticleID=2056|archivedate=September 6, 2005|df=mdy-all}} * {{Cite book|title=Celebrate the Solstice|author=Richard Heinberg|publisher=Quest Books|location=U.S.|date=September 1993|isbn=0-8356-0693-7}} * {{Cite journal|title=Seasonality and Competition in Time: An Empirical Analysis of Release Date Decisions in the U.S. Motion Picture Industry|date=August 12, 2002|author=Liran Einav|url=http://www.stanford.edu/~leinav/Release_Dates.pdf|format=PDF}} – Einav describes the Christmas and holiday season as one of the two periods of the year (the other being the beginning of Summer, [[Memorial Day]] to [[Labor Day]]) where "movie makers [...] tend to release their biggest hits".
== External links == {{Wikivoyage|Christmas and New Year travel}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20101224171158/http://backstoryradio.org/happy-holidays-a-history-of-the-season/ ''Naughty & Nice: A History of the Holiday Season''] - An hour-long public radio program exploring the roots of American beliefs and rituals surrounding the winter holidays * {{Cite news|publisher=The New York Times|work=The Learning Network: Issues in Depth|title=Winter Holidays|url=https://www.nytimes.com/learning/general/specials/season/#holidays|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020228010700/http://www.nytimes.com/learning/general/specials/season/#holidays|archivedate=February 28, 2002}} – A series of lesson plans for teaching children about the winter holidays.
